question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $f(x)=|x-p|+|x-15|+|x-p-15|,$ where $0 < p < 15.$ Determine the minimum value taken by $f(x)$ for $x$ in the interval $p \leq x\leq15.$
inference:
Since $f(x)=|x-p|+|x-15|+|x-p-15|=|x-p|+|x-15|-|x-p-15|,$ we have that $$f'(x)=\begin{cases} 1 &\text{if } x

p+15 \end{cases}.$$ Thus, $f$ is increasing on $[p,p+15]$ and decreasing on $(p+15,15].$ Therefore, the minimum value of $f(x)$ on $[p,15]$ occurs at $x=p+15.$ Thus, $$f(p+15)=|p+15-p|+|p+15-15|+|p+15-p-15|=|15|+|0|+|0|=15.$$ Final Answer: $\boxed{15}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: Since $0 < p \le x \le 15,$ the absolute values simplify to \[f(x) = (x-p) - (x-15) - (x-p-15) = -x+30.\]The value of this expression is minimized when $x=15,$ giving $-15+30=\boxed{15}.$
